00031 /*
00032    Scanner for the DDS. This file works with gnu's flex scanner generator. It
00033    returns either DATASET, INDEPENDENT, DEPENDENT, ARRAY, MAPS, LIST,
00034    SEQUENCE, STRUCTURE, FUNCTION, GRID, BYTE, INT32, FLOAT64, STRING, URL, ID
00035    or one of the single character tokens `{', `}', `;', `=' or `\n' as
00036    integers. In the case of an ID, the scanner stores a pointer to the lexeme
00037    in yylval (whose type is char *).
00038 
00039    The scanner discards all comment text.
00040 
00041    The scanner is not reentrant, but can share name spaces with other
00042    scanners.
00043    
00044    Note:
00045    1) The `defines' file dds.tab.h is built using `bison -d'.
00046    2) Define YY_DECL such that the scanner is called `ddslex'.
00047    3) When bison builds the dds.tab.h file, it uses `dds' instead of `yy' for
00048    variable name prefixes (e.g., yylval --> ddslval).
00049    
00050    jhrg 8/29/94 
00051 */
00052 
00053 %{
00054 
00055 #include "config_dap.h"
00056 
00057 static char rcsid[] not_used = {"$Id$"};
00058 
00059 #include <string.h>
00060 
00061 // #include "Error.h"
00062 #include "parser.h"
00063 #include "dds.tab.h"
00064 #include "escaping.h"
00065 
00066 #define YY_DECL int ddslex YY_PROTO(( void ))
00067 #define YY_INPUT(buf,result,max_size) { \
00068     fgets((buf), (max_size), yyin); \
00069     result = (feof(yyin) || strcmp(buf, "Data:\n") == 0) \
00070              ? YY_NULL : strlen(buf); \
00071 }
00072 
00073 int dds_line_num = 1;
00074 
00075 static void store_word();
00076 
00077 %}
00078     
00079 %option noyywrap
00080 %x comment
00081 
00082 DATASET     DATASET|Dataset|dataset 
00083 LIST        LIST|List|list
00084 SEQUENCE    SEQUENCE|Sequence|sequence
00085 STRUCTURE   STRUCTURE|Structure|structure
00086 GRID        GRID|Grid|grid
00087 BYTE        BYTE|Byte|byte
00088 INT16       INT16|Int16|int16
00089 UINT16      UINT16|UInt16|uint16
00090 INT32       INT32|Int32|int32
00091 UINT32      UINT32|UInt32|uint32
00092 FLOAT32     FLOAT32|Float32|float32
00093 FLOAT64     FLOAT64|Float64|float64
00094 STRING      STRING|String|string
00095 URL         URL|Url|url
00096 
00097 /* See das.lex for comments about the characters allowed in a WORD.
00098    10/31/2001 jhrg */
00099 
00100 WORD            [-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\*][-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\#*]*
00101 
00102 NEVER       [^\-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\#;,(){}[\]]
00103 
00104 %%
00105 
00106 "{"                     return (int)*yytext;
00107 "}"                     return (int)*yytext;
00108 "["         return (int)*yytext;
00109 "]"         return (int)*yytext;
00110 ":"         return (int)*yytext;
00111 ";"                     return (int)*yytext;
00112 "="         return (int)*yytext;
00113 
00114 {DATASET}       store_word(); return SCAN_DATASET;
00115 {LIST}          store_word(); return SCAN_LIST;
00116 {SEQUENCE}      store_word(); return SCAN_SEQUENCE;
00117 {STRUCTURE}     store_word(); return SCAN_STRUCTURE;
00118 {GRID}          store_word(); return SCAN_GRID;
00119 {BYTE}          store_word(); return SCAN_BYTE;
00120 {INT16}         store_word(); return SCAN_INT16;
00121 {UINT16}        store_word(); return SCAN_UINT16;
00122 {INT32}         store_word(); return SCAN_INT32;
00123 {UINT32}        store_word(); return SCAN_UINT32;
00124 {FLOAT32}       store_word(); return SCAN_FLOAT32;
00125 {FLOAT64}       store_word(); return SCAN_FLOAT64;
00126 {STRING}        store_word(); return SCAN_STRING;
00127 {URL}           store_word(); return SCAN_URL;
00128 
00129 {WORD}                  store_word(); return SCAN_WORD;
00130 
00131 [ \t\r]+
00132 \n                  ++dds_line_num;
00133 <INITIAL><<EOF>>        yy_init = 1; dds_line_num = 1; yyterminate();
00134 
00135 "#"                 BEGIN(comment);
00136 <comment>[^\n]*
00137 <comment>\n     ++dds_line_num; BEGIN(INITIAL);
00138 <comment><<EOF>>        yy_init = 1; dds_line_num = 1; yyterminate();
00139 
00140 "Data:\n"       yyterminate();
00141 "Data:\r\n"     yyterminate();
00142 
00143 {NEVER}                 {
00144                           if (yytext) { /* suppress msgs about `' chars */
00145                             fprintf(stderr, "Character `%c' is not", *yytext);
00146                             fprintf(stderr, " allowed and has been ignored\n");
00147               }
00148             }
00149 %%
00150 
00151 static void
00152 store_word()
00153 {
00154     // dods2id(string(yytext)).c_str()
00155     strncpy(ddslval.word, yytext, ID_MAX-1);
00156     ddslval.word[ID_MAX-1] = '\0'; // for the paranoid...
00157 }

00175  * Revision 1.34  2003/01/10 19:46:41  jimg
00176  * Merged with code tagged release-3-2-10 on the release-3-2 branch. In many
00177  * cases files were added on that branch (so they appear on the trunk for
00178  * the first time).
00179  *
00180  * Revision 1.30.2.5  2002/06/11 00:40:52  jimg
00181  * I added '*' to the set of characters allowed in a WORD in both the DAS
00182  * and DDS scanners. It's not allowed in the expr scanner because that
00183  * would cause conflicts with the URL dereference operator.
00184  *
00185  * Revision 1.33  2002/06/03 22:21:15  jimg
00186  * Merged with release-3-2-9
00187  *
00188  * Revision 1.30.2.4  2001/11/01 00:43:51  jimg
00189  * Fixes to the scanners and parsers so that dataset variable names may
00190  * start with digits. I've expanded the set of characters that may appear
00191  * in a variable name and made it so that all except `#' may appear at
00192  * the start. Some characters are not allowed in variables that appear in
00193  * a DDS or CE while they are allowed in the DAS. This makes it possible
00194  * to define containers with names like `COARDS:long_name.' Putting a colon
00195  * in a variable name makes the CE parser much more complex. Since the set
00196  * of characters that people want seems pretty limited (compared to the
00197  * complete ASCII set) I think this is an OK approach. If we have to open
00198  * up the expr.lex scanner completely, then we can but not without adding
00199  * lots of action clauses to teh parser. Note that colon is just an example,
00200  * there's a host of characters that are used in CEs that are not allowed
00201  * in IDs.
00202  *
00203  * Revision 1.32  2001/08/24 17:46:22  jimg
00204  * Resolved conflicts from the merge of release 3.2.6
00205  *
00206  * Revision 1.30.2.3  2001/08/16 17:26:20  edavis
00207  * Use "%option noyywrap" instead of defining yywrap() to return 1.
00208  *
00209  * Revision 1.30.2.2  2001/06/23 00:52:08  jimg
00210  * Normalized the definitions of ID (SCAN_ID), INT, FLOAT and NEVER so
00211  * that they are (more or less) the same in all the scanners. There are
00212  * one or two characters that differ (for example das.lex allows ( and )
00213  * in an ID while dds.lex, expr.lex and gse.lex don't) but the definitions
00214  * are essentially the same across the board.
00215  * Added `#' to the set of characeters allowed in an ID (bug 179).
00216  *
00217  * Revision 1.31  2001/06/15 23:49:03  jimg
00218  * Merged with release-3-2-4.
00219  *
00220  * Revision 1.30.2.1  2001/05/08 19:10:47  jimg
00221  * Expanded the set of names that the dds.y parser will recognize to
00222  * include integers (for files named like 990412.nc). Also removed the
00223  * unused keywords Dependent and Independent from both the DDS scanner
00224  * and parser.
00225  * Added other reserved words to the set of possible Dataset names.
00226  *
00227  * Revision 1.30  2000/10/30 17:21:28  jimg
00228  * Added support for proxy servers (from cjm).
00229  *
00230  * Revision 1.29  2000/09/07 23:08:52  jimg
00231  * Fixed another goof from the last merge; I dropped the new feature that
00232  * identifiers can have dots i their names. This feature could really screw
00233  * things up, but it is needed for translation. It should be the case that the
00234  * CE evaluator never sees such a variable name (since the translation software
00235  * should get to it first and rearrange things).
00236  *

00245  * Added \r to the set of characters that are ignored. This is an untested fix
00246  * (?) for UNIX clients that read from servers run on win32 machines (e.g.,
00247  * the Java-SQL server can be run on a win32 box).
00248  *
00249  * Revision 1.24  1999/05/04 19:47:23  jimg

00253  * Merge of no-gnu branch
00254  *
00255  * Revision 1.22  1999/03/24 23:32:49  jimg
00256  * Added support for the new Int16, UInt16 and Float32 types.
00257  *
00258  * Revision 1.21  1999/02/23 01:30:57  jimg
00259  * Added a YYINPUT define that looks for `Data:\n'. When seen it returns
00260  * YY_NULL which tells the scanner that EOF has been found. This hack keeps
00261  * flex from reading into the data while buffering from the input source. This
00262  * means that the calling code does not have to rewind the input to find the
00263  * start of the data. Of course, multi-part MIME docs would also solve this.
00264  * Replace this hack with MP/MIME code!
00265  *
00266  * Revision 1.20  1999/01/21 02:51:27  jimg
00267  * The dds scanner now recognizes the token `Data:' as an EOF marker. This
00268  * means that the data document can be scanned without splitting the DDS and
00269  * binary data parts into two files.
00270  *
00271  * Revision 1.19.6.1  1999/02/05 09:32:36  jimg
00272  * Fixed __unused__ so that it not longer clashes with Red Hat 5.2 inlined
00273  * math code.

00278  * Revision 1.18  1998/02/05 20:14:01  jimg
00279  * DODS now compiles with gcc 2.8.x
00280  *
00281  * Revision 1.17  1997/12/16 00:46:29  jimg
00282  * Added `-' to characters allowed in NAME lexeme.
00283  *
00284  * Revision 1.16  1997/11/20 20:12:14  jimg
00285  * Added the NAME lexeme. This is explicitly for datasets with `.' in their
00286  * names. That character cannot be used in the name of a variable since in
00287  * DODS it separates parts of a constructor type. However, it can be part of
00288  * a dataset name. Using a separate lexeme is required by the parser.
00289  *
